newsitem.title: GERMANY: BASF shares dip after negative drug news.
newsitem.headline: BASF shares dip after negative drug news.

text.p: Shares in German chemicals group BASF AG fell 2.25 percent in pre-bourse trade on Friday after a U.S. drug regulatory group recommended that approval for one of the group's new products should be withheld.

BASF shares fell 1.10 marks to 47.90 marks after a U.S. advisory committee on Thursday recommended that the Food and Drug Administration should withold approval for a new BASF drug called Meridia, used in treating obesity.
The broader market was also down, slipping 0.28 percent to 2,657.53 points.
BASF management board member Dieter Stein in April predicted Meridia would be a very successful new product, posting sales somewhere between $200 and $400 million annually.
Members of the Endocrinologic and Metabolic Drugs Advisory Committee agreed that the one-a-day anti-obesity capsules were effective but said they still had a number of questions about its safety.
The FDA is not bound by the recommendations of its advisory committees, but usually accepts them.
